title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: vignette demonstrates : Perform multiple imputation using {rbmi} package Store modify imputed data using rbmiUtils standard ANCOVA continuous endpoint (CHG) binary responder analysis CRIT1FLN using {beeca} pattern enables reproducible workflows imputation analysis can separated revisited independently. Related vignettes: Data Preparation Validation - Validate data imputation Efficient Storage Imputed Data - Reduce storage large imputations

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: approach applies Rubin’s Rules inference multiple imputation (see rbmi quickstart vignette background draws/impute/analyse/pool pipeline): fit model imputed dataset, derive response variable CHG score, extract marginal effects statistics interest, combine results single inference using Rubin’s combining rules.

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(readr) library(purrr) library(rbmi) library(beeca) library(rbmiUtils) set.seed(1974) data("ADEFF")  ADEFF <- ADEFF %>%   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT)   )

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: use rbmi::set_vars() specify key variable roles:

control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) ) dat <- ADEFF %>%   select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, REGIONC, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT)  draws_obj <- draws(data = dat, vars = vars, method = method) #> title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
code: ADMI <- ADMI %>%   mutate(     CRIT1FLN = ifelse(CHG > 3, 1, 0),     CRIT1FL = ifelse(CRIT1FLN == 1, "Y", "N"),     CRIT = "CHG > 3"   )

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
code: ana_obj_ancova <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI,   vars = vars,   method = method,   fun = ancova ) pool_obj_ancova <- pool(ana_obj_ancova) print(pool_obj_ancova) #>  #> ── Pool Object ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> 6 parameters across 2 visits #> Method: rubin #> N imputations: 100 #> Confidence: 95% #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>        parameter   visit   est   lci   uci    pval #>      trt_Week 24 Week 24 -2.18 -2.54 -1.82 < 0.001 #>  lsm_ref_Week 24 Week 24  0.08 -0.18  0.33   0.559 #>  lsm_alt_Week 24 Week 24 -2.10 -2.35 -1.85 < 0.001 #>      trt_Week 48 Week 48 -3.81 -4.31 -3.30 < 0.001 #>  lsm_ref_Week 48 Week 48  0.04 -0.32  0.41   0.812 #>  lsm_alt_Week 48 Week 48 -3.76 -4.11 -3.42 < 0.001 tidy_pool_obj(pool_obj_ancova) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   parameter       description visit parameter_type lsm_type     est    se    lci #>   <chr>           <chr>       <chr> <chr>          <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 trt_Week 24     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -2.18   0.182 -2.54  #> 2 lsm_ref_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0765 0.131 -0.181 #> 3 lsm_alt_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -2.10   0.126 -2.35  #> 4 trt_Week 48     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -3.81   0.256 -4.31  #> 5 lsm_ref_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0440 0.185 -0.320 #> 6 lsm_alt_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -3.76   0.175 -4.11  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: uci <dbl>, pval <dbl>

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: use beeca::get_marginal_effect() robust variance estimation marginal treatment effects logistic model:
code: gcomp_responder <- function(data, ...) {   model <- glm(CRIT1FLN ~ TRT + BASE + STRATA + REGION, data = data, family = binomial)    marginal_fit <- get_marginal_effect(     model,     trt = "TRT",     method = "Ge",     type = "HC0",     contrast = "diff",     reference = "Placebo"   )    res <- marginal_fit$marginal_results   list(     trt = list(       est = res[res$STAT == "diff", "STATVAL"][[1]],       se = res[res$STAT == "diff_se", "STATVAL"][[1]],       df = NA     )   ) }

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
code: vars_binary <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CRIT1FLN",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) ana_obj_prop <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI,   vars = vars_binary,   method = method,   fun = gcomp_responder ) pool_obj_prop <- pool(ana_obj_prop) print(pool_obj_prop) #>  #> ── Pool Object ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> 1 parameter across 0 visits #> Method: rubin #> N imputations: 100 #> Confidence: 95% #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  parameter visit   est   lci   uci    pval #>        trt  <NA> -0.06 -0.09 -0.04 < 0.001

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: working many imputations, consider using reduce_imputed_data() store imputed values: See Efficient Storage vignette details.
code: # Reduce for efficient storage reduced <- reduce_imputed_data(ADMI, ADEFF, vars)  # Later, expand back for analysis ADMI_restored <- expand_imputed_data(reduced, ADEFF, vars)

title: Storing and Analyzing Imputed Data with rbmiUtils
text: guided tutorial walking complete pipeline raw data regulatory tables, see vignette('pipeline').

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: vignette demonstrates prepare validate data running multiple imputation {rbmi}. rbmiUtils package provides three key functions workflow: validate_data(): Pre-flight validation catch common data issues prepare_data_ice(): Build intercurrent event data flag columns summarise_missingness(): Understand missing data patterns Using functions helps ensure imputation run successfully gives insight structure missing data.

title: Data Preparation and Validation
code: library(dplyr) library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils)

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: ’ll create small example dataset demonstrate functions:
code: set.seed(42)  dat <- data.frame(  USUBJID = factor(rep(paste0("SUBJ-", 1:20), each = 4)),  AVISIT = factor(    rep(c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12", "Week 16"), 20),    levels = c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12", "Week 16")  ),  TRT = factor(rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A"), each = 40)),  BASE = rep(round(rnorm(20, 50, 10), 1), each = 4),  STRATA = factor(rep(sample(c("Low", "High"), 20, replace = TRUE), each = 4)) )  # Generate CHG with some missing values dat$CHG <- round(rnorm(80, mean = -2, sd = 3), 1)  # Create missing data patterns: # - Subjects 3, 8: monotone dropout at Week 12 # - Subject 15: intermittent missing at Week 8 # - Subject 18: monotone dropout at Week 16 dat$CHG[dat$USUBJID == "SUBJ-3" & dat$AVISIT %in% c("Week 12", "Week 16")] <- NA dat$CHG[dat$USUBJID == "SUBJ-8" & dat$AVISIT %in% c("Week 12", "Week 16")] <- NA dat$CHG[dat$USUBJID == "SUBJ-15" & dat$AVISIT == "Week 8"] <- NA dat$CHG[dat$USUBJID == "SUBJ-18" & dat$AVISIT == "Week 16"] <- NA  # Add discontinuation flag dat$DISCFL <- ifelse(  dat$USUBJID %in% c("SUBJ-3", "SUBJ-8") & dat$AVISIT == "Week 12",  "Y",  ifelse(    dat$USUBJID == "SUBJ-18" & dat$AVISIT == "Week 16",    "Y",    "N"  ) )  head(dat, 12) #>    USUBJID  AVISIT     TRT BASE STRATA  CHG DISCFL #> 1   SUBJ-1  Week 4 Placebo 63.7    Low -0.6      N #> 2   SUBJ-1  Week 8 Placebo 63.7    Low  0.1      N #> 3   SUBJ-1 Week 12 Placebo 63.7    Low  1.1      N #> 4   SUBJ-1 Week 16 Placebo 63.7    Low -3.8      N #> 5   SUBJ-2  Week 4 Placebo 44.4    Low -0.5      N #> 6   SUBJ-2  Week 8 Placebo 44.4    Low -7.2      N #> 7   SUBJ-2 Week 12 Placebo 44.4    Low -4.4      N #> 8   SUBJ-2 Week 16 Placebo 44.4    Low -4.6      N #> 9   SUBJ-3  Week 4 Placebo 53.6   High -9.2      N #> 10  SUBJ-3  Week 8 Placebo 53.6   High -1.9      N #> 11  SUBJ-3 Week 12 Placebo 53.6   High   NA      Y #> 12  SUBJ-3 Week 16 Placebo 53.6   High   NA      N

title: Data Preparation and Validation
code: vars <- set_vars(  subjid = "USUBJID",  visit = "AVISIT",  group = "TRT",  outcome = "CHG",  covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA"),  strategy = "STRATEGY" )

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: validate_data() function performs comprehensive checks data imputation: function checks: Data data.frame required columns exist (subjid, visit, group, outcome, covariates) Factor columns properly typed Outcome column numeric Covariates missing values duplicate subject-visit combinations data_ice provided: valid subjects, visits, strategies
code: # This will pass validation validate_data(dat, vars)

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: ’s example validation catches issues:
code: # Create problematic data bad_dat <- dat bad_dat$TRT <- as.character(bad_dat$TRT)  # Should be factor bad_dat$BASE[1] <- NA  # Covariate with missing value  # This will report all issues at once tryCatch(  validate_data(bad_dat, vars),  error = function(e) cat(e$message) ) #> Warning: 1 column is character instead of factor. #> ℹ Column: TRT. #> ℹ `rbmi::draws()` will auto-coerce, but explicit conversion gives you control #>   over level ordering. #> ℹ Example: `data$TRT <- factor(data$TRT)` #> Data validation failed.

text: three pattern types : complete: missing outcome values monotone: value missing, subsequent visits also missing (dropout) intermittent: Missing values observed values

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: subjects discontinue treatment, may want apply reference-based imputation strategies (see {rbmi} documentation details intercurrent event handling). prepare_data_ice() function builds required data_ice data.frame discontinuation flag: function: Identifies subjects ICE flags ("Y", TRUE, 1) Takes first flagged visit per subject Assigns specified imputation strategy Available strategies : "MAR": Missing Random "CR": Copy Reference "JR": Jump Reference "CIR": Copy Increment Reference "LMCF": Last Mean Carried Forward
code: data_ice <- prepare_data_ice(  data = dat,  vars = vars,  ice_col = "DISCFL",  strategy = "JR"  # Jump to Reference )  print(data_ice) #>   USUBJID  AVISIT STRATEGY #> 1 SUBJ-18 Week 16       JR #> 2  SUBJ-3 Week 12       JR #> 3  SUBJ-8 Week 12       JR

title: Data Preparation and Validation
text: ’s functions fit typical {rbmi} workflow:
code: library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils)  # 1. Validate data validate_data(dat, vars)  # 2. Understand missing patterns miss <- summarise_missingness(dat, vars) print(miss$summary)  # 3. Prepare ICE data if needed data_ice <- prepare_data_ice(dat, vars, ice_col = "DISCFL", strategy = "JR")  # 4. Define method method <- method_bayes(  n_samples = 100,  control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) )  # 5. Run imputation draws_obj <- draws(  data = dat,  vars = vars,  data_ice = data_ice,  method = method )  # 6. Continue with impute() and analyse()

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: rbmi multiple imputation pipeline produces several intermediate objects – draws, imputation, analysis, pool – containing useful metadata imputation model results. rbmiUtils v0.3.0 adds tools inspect objects extract diagnostic statistics, making easier verify MI pipeline behaved expected. vignette covers three features: describe_draws(): structured metadata draws objects (method, formula, samples, MCMC convergence) describe_imputation(): structured metadata imputation objects (method, M, references, missingness breakdown) pool_to_ard() MI diagnostic enrichment: fraction missing information (FMI), lambda, relative increase variance (RIV), Rubin’s rules diagnostics embedded ARD output

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: load required packages prepare data pool_to_ard() diagnostic enrichment examples Section 5. setup uses analyse_mi_data() works directly pre-imputed ADMI dataset (containing IMPID column), need draws() impute().
code: library(rbmiUtils) library(rbmi) library(dplyr)  data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils") ADMI <- ADMI |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT)   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) method <- method_bayes(   n_samples = 100,   control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 5) )  ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(ADMI, vars, method, fun = ancova) pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj)

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: describe_draws() function extracts structured metadata rbmi draws object, providing quick summary imputation model configuration , Bayesian methods, MCMC convergence diagnostics. code uses ADEFF data defines vars method objects. use eval = FALSE draws() runs MCMC sampling, slow vignette builds. Example output describe_draws(): returned object list programmatic access fields: $method – human-readable method name (e.g., “Bayesian (MCMC via Stan)”) $method_class – raw class: "bayes", "approxbayes", "condmean" $formula – deparsed model formula string $n_samples – total number samples drawn $n_failures – number failed samples $mcmc – (Bayesian ) list rhat, ess, max_rhat, min_ess, n_params, converged
code: data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils") ADEFF <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT, levels = c("Week 24", "Week 48"))   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) method <- method_bayes(   n_samples = 100,   control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) )  dat <- ADEFF |> select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT) draws_obj <- draws(data = dat, vars = vars, method = method) desc <- describe_draws(draws_obj) print(desc) -- Draws Summary -- Method: Bayesian (MCMC via Stan) Formula: CHG ~ 1 + BASE + STRATA + REGION + TRT + AVISIT + TRT:AVISIT Samples: 100 Failures: 0 Covariance: us Same covariance across groups: Yes -- -- MCMC Convergence -- v All Rhat < 1.1 (42 parameters) Max Rhat: 1.003 Min ESS: 245.2

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: describe_imputation() function extracts metadata rbmi imputation object, including method, number imputations (M), reference arm mappings, missingness breakdown visit treatment arm. section continues draws_obj created code (Section 3). , use eval = FALSE pipeline requires MCMC. Example output describe_imputation(): returned object provides programmatic access : $method – human-readable method name $n_imputations – number imputations (M) $n_subjects – total number unique subjects $references – named character vector reference arm mappings (NULL) $missingness – data.frame columns visit, group, n_total, n_miss, pct_miss
code: impute_obj <- impute(   draws_obj,   references = c("Placebo" = "Placebo", "Drug A" = "Placebo") ) desc <- describe_imputation(impute_obj) print(desc) -- Imputation Summary -- Method: Bayesian (MCMC via Stan) Imputations (M): 100 Subjects: 200 -- -- References -- Placebo -> Placebo Drug A -> Placebo -- Missingness by Visit and Arm --     visit   group n_total n_miss pct_miss   Week 24 Placebo     100      8      8.0   Week 24  Drug A     100     10     10.0   Week 48 Placebo     100     15     15.0   Week 48  Drug A     100     18     18.0

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: pool_to_ard() function converts pool object pharmaverse Analysis Results Dataset (ARD) format. also pass analysis_obj, enriches ARD MI diagnostic statistics computed Rubin’s rules. enriched ARD includes additional rows parameter diagnostic statistics. can filter display : diagnostic statistic specific interpretation: FMI (fraction missing information) – adjusted proportion total sampling variance attributable missing data, following mice convention: (riv + 2/(df + 3)) / (1 + riv) lambda – proportion total variance due -imputation variance (missingness) RIV (relative increase variance) – ratio -imputation variance within-imputation variance, scaled (1 + 1/M) df.adjusted – Barnard-Rubin adjusted degrees freedom, accounts finite complete-data degrees freedom re (relative efficiency) – 1 / (1 + fmi/M), efficiency MI estimator relative estimator infinite imputations
code: # Base ARD (no diagnostics) ard <- pool_to_ard(pool_obj)  # Enriched ARD with MI diagnostics ard_enriched <- pool_to_ard(pool_obj, analysis_obj = ana_obj) ard_enriched |>   dplyr::filter(stat_name %in% c("fmi", "lambda", "riv", "df.adjusted", "re")) |>   dplyr::select(group1_level, variable_level, stat_name, stat) #> {cards} data frame: 30 x 4 #>    group1_level variable_level   stat_name    stat #> 1       Week 24             NA         fmi   0.023 #> 2       Week 24             NA      lambda   0.019 #> 3       Week 24             NA         riv   0.019 #> 4       Week 24             NA df.adjusted 480.772 #> 5       Week 24             NA          re       1 #> 6       Week 24             NA         fmi   0.021 #> 7       Week 24             NA      lambda   0.017 #> 8       Week 24             NA         riv   0.018 #> 9       Week 24             NA df.adjusted 481.809 #> 10      Week 24             NA          re       1 #> ℹ 20 more rows #> ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows

title: MI Diagnostics and Pipeline Inspection
text: Non-Rubin pooling methods (e.g., conditional mean jackknife) produce MI diagnostic statistics variance decomposition apply. pool_to_ard() called analysis_obj non-Rubin method, emits informative message omits diagnostic rows ARD. describe_draws() describe_imputation() functions work method types (Bayesian, approximate Bayesian, conditional mean).

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: performing multiple imputation {rbmi} using many imputations (e.g., 100-1000), full imputed dataset can become large. However, data redundant: observed values identical across imputations. rbmiUtils package provides two functions address : reduce_imputed_data(): Extract imputed values (originally missing) expand_imputed_data(): Reconstruct full dataset needed approach can reduce storage requirements 90% , depending proportion missing data.

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: Consider typical clinical trial dataset: 500 subjects 5 visits per subject = 2,500 rows 5% missing data = 125 missing values 1,000 imputations Full storage: 2,500 rows × 1,000 imputations = 2.5 million rows Reduced storage: 125 missing values × 1,000 imputations = 125,000 rows (5% full size)

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
code: library(dplyr) library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils)

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: rbmiUtils package includes example datasets can use:
code: data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils")  # Full imputed dataset data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils") # Original data with missing values  # Check dimensions cat("Full imputed dataset (ADMI):", nrow(ADMI), "rows\n") #> Full imputed dataset (ADMI): 100000 rows cat("Number of imputations:", length(unique(ADMI$IMPID)), "\n") #> Number of imputations: 100

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: First, prepare original data match imputed data structure: Define variables specification: Now reduce imputed data:
code:
original <- ADEFF |>  mutate(    TRT = TRT01P,    USUBJID = as.character(USUBJID)  )  # Count missing values n_missing <- sum(is.na(original$CHG)) cat("Missing values in original data:", n_missing, "
") #> Missing values in original data: 44 vars <- set_vars(  subjid = "USUBJID",  visit = "AVISIT",  group = "TRT",  outcome = "CHG" ) reduced <- reduce_imputed_data(ADMI, original, vars)  cat("Full imputed rows:", nrow(ADMI), "
") #> Full imputed rows: 100000 cat("Reduced rows:", nrow(reduced), "

") #> Compression ratio: 4.4 %

code: # First few rows head(reduced) #> # A tibble: 6 × 12 #>   IMPID STRATA REGION  REGIONC TRT    BASE   CHG AVISIT USUBJID CRIT1FLN CRIT1FL #>   <dbl> <chr>  <chr>     <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>      <dbl> <chr>   #> 1     1 A      North …       1 Plac…    12 -1.96 Week … ID011          0 N       #> 2     1 A      Europe        3 Drug…     3 -3.71 Week … ID014          0 N       #> 3     1 B      Europe        3 Drug…     9 -1.96 Week … ID018          0 N       #> 4     1 A      Asia          4 Drug…    10 -5.55 Week … ID033          0 N       #> 5     1 A      Asia          4 Drug…     0 -1.28 Week … ID061          0 N       #> 6     1 A      South …       2 Plac…     5 -2.60 Week … ID071          0 N       #> # ℹ 1 more variable: CRIT <chr>  # Structure matches original imputed data cat("\nColumns in reduced data:\n") #>  #> Columns in reduced data: cat(paste(names(reduced), collapse = ", ")) #> IMPID, STRATA, REGION, REGIONC, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT, USUBJID, CRIT1FLN, CRIT1FL, CRIT

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: need run analyses, expand reduced data back full form:
code: expanded <- expand_imputed_data(reduced, original, vars)  cat("Expanded rows:", nrow(expanded), "\n") #> Expanded rows: 100000 cat("Original ADMI rows:", nrow(ADMI), "\n") #> Original ADMI rows: 100000

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
text: Let’s verify round-trip preserves data integrity:
code: # Sort both datasets for comparison admi_sorted <- ADMI |>  arrange(IMPID, USUBJID, AVISIT)  expanded_sorted <- expanded |>  arrange(IMPID, USUBJID, AVISIT)  # Compare CHG values all_equal <- all.equal(  admi_sorted$CHG,  expanded_sorted$CHG,  tolerance = 1e-10 )  cat("Data integrity check:", all_equal, "\n") #> Data integrity check: TRUE

text: ’s integrate efficient storage workflow:

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
code: # After imputation impute_obj <- impute(draws_obj, references = c("Placebo" = "Placebo", "Drug A" = "Placebo")) full_imputed <- get_imputed_data(impute_obj)  # Reduce for storage reduced <- reduce_imputed_data(full_imputed, original_data, vars)  # Save both (reduced is much smaller) saveRDS(reduced, "imputed_reduced.rds") saveRDS(original_data, "original_data.rds")

title: Efficient Storage of Imputed Data
code: # Load saved data reduced <- readRDS("imputed_reduced.rds") original_data <- readRDS("original_data.rds")  # Expand when needed for analysis full_imputed <- expand_imputed_data(reduced, original_data, vars)  # Run analysis ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(  data = full_imputed,  vars = vars,  method = method,  fun = ancova )

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: Clinical trial analyses use reference-based multiple imputation typically involve several steps: fitting imputation model, generating imputed datasets, applying analysis dataset, pooling results using Rubin’s rules. rbmi package implements pipeline draws(), impute(), analyse(), pool() functions. However, turning pooled results publication-ready outputs – formatted tables forest plots suitable regulatory submissions – requires additional work. rbmiUtils package bridges gap. provides utilities sit top rbmi, transforming pooled analysis objects tidy data frames, regulatory-style efficacy tables, three-panel forest plots. also includes data preparation helpers catch common issues computationally expensive imputation step. vignette, walk complete pipeline raw clinical trial data two publication-ready outputs: efficacy summary table forest plot. end, seen every major step typical rbmi + rbmiUtils workflow. focused reference analysis functions, see analyse2 vignette. detailed guidance data preparation, see data preparation vignette.

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: begin loading packages need. core pipeline requires rbmi rbmiUtils, dplyr data manipulation. reporting outputs use gt (tables) ggplot2 + patchwork (plots), optional dependencies. ADEFF dataset bundled rbmiUtils simulated ADaM-style efficacy dataset two-arm clinical trial. contains continuous change--baseline outcomes (CHG) measured two visits (Week 24 Week 48), realistic missing data patterns across 500 subjects. entering rbmi pipeline, convert key grouping columns factors. Factor levels control ordering treatment arms visits throughout analysis, important set explicitly.
code: library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils) library(dplyr) data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils") str(ADEFF) #> tibble [1,000 × 10] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ USUBJID: chr [1:1000] "ID001" "ID001" "ID002" "ID002" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Unique patient identifier" #>  $ STRATA : chr [1:1000] "A" "A" "A" "A" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Stratification at randomisation" #>  $ REGION : chr [1:1000] "North America" "North America" "Asia" "Asia" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Stratification by region" #>  $ REGIONC: num [1:1000] 1 1 4 4 2 2 3 3 2 2 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Stratification by region, numeric code" #>  $ TRT01P : chr [1:1000] "Drug A" "Drug A" "Drug A" "Drug A" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Planned treatment" #>  $ BASE   : num [1:1000] 16 16 10 10 12 12 11 11 9 9 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Baseline value of primary outcome variable" #>  $ AVISIT : chr [1:1000] "Week 24" "Week 48" "Week 24" "Week 48" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Visit number" #>  $ AVAL   : num [1:1000] 12 13 7 5 9 10 9 13 4 0 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Primary outcome variable" #>  $ PARAM  : chr [1:1000] "ESSDAI score" "ESSDAI score" "ESSDAI score" "ESSDAI score" ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Analysis parameter name" #>  $ CHG    : num [1:1000] -4 -3 -3 -5 -3 -2 -2 2 -5 -9 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Change from baseline" ADEFF <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT, levels = c("Week 24", "Week 48"))   )

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: data validated, now run core rbmi pipeline. consists four steps: specifying imputation method, fitting imputation model, generating imputed datasets, analysing one.

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: method_bayes() function configures Bayesian multiple imputation using MCMC sampling. use small number samples short warmup period keep vignette build time manageable. real analysis, typically use samples (e.g., n_samples = 500 ) better precision. details statistical methodology, see rbmi quickstart vignette.
code: set.seed(1974)  method <- method_bayes(   n_samples = 100,   control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) )

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: draws() function fits Bayesian imputation model. computationally intensive step pipeline. pass dataset columns needed model.
code: dat <- ADEFF |>   select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT)  draws_obj <- draws(data = dat, vars = vars, method = method) #> Running /opt/R/4.5.2/lib/R/bin/R CMD SHLIB foo.c #> using C compiler: ‘gcc (Ubuntu 13.3.0-6ubuntu2~24.04) 13.3.0’ #> gcc -std=gnu2x -I"/opt/R/4.5.2/lib/R/include" -DNDEBUG   -I"/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/Rcpp/include/" title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: impute() function generates complete datasets specified reference-based assumption. use jump--reference approach arms imputed reference (Placebo) distribution.
code: impute_obj <- impute(   draws_obj,   references = c("Placebo" = "Placebo", "Drug A" = "Placebo") )

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: Rather calling rbmi::analyse() directly, rbmiUtils provides analyse_mi_data(), wraps analyse step work stacked imputed data format. applies analysis function – , built-ancova function – imputed dataset stores results pooling. First, extract imputed data stacked data frame using get_imputed_data(): analyse:
code: ADMI <- get_imputed_data(impute_obj) ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI,   vars = vars,   method = method,   fun = ancova )

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: Finally, pool() combines per-imputation results using Rubin’s rules produce single set estimates, standard errors, confidence intervals, p-values.

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: pool object contains information need, structure immediately convenient reporting. tidy_pool_obj() function converts tidy tibble clearly labelled columns. row represents one parameter one visit. key columns : parameter: raw parameter name pool object parameter_type: "trt" treatment differences, "lsm" least squares means lsm_type: "ref" "alt" LS mean rows visit: visit name est, se, lci, uci, pval: numeric results tidy format foundation downstream reporting. can filter, reshape, format needed specific tables.
code: tidy_df <- tidy_pool_obj(pool_obj) print(tidy_df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   parameter       description visit parameter_type lsm_type     est    se    lci #>   <chr>           <chr>       <chr> <chr>          <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 trt_Week 24     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -2.18   0.182 -2.54  #> 2 lsm_ref_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0765 0.131 -0.181 #> 3 lsm_alt_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -2.10   0.126 -2.35  #> 4 trt_Week 48     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -3.81   0.256 -4.31  #> 5 lsm_ref_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0440 0.185 -0.320 #> 6 lsm_alt_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -3.76   0.175 -4.11  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: uci <dbl>, pval <dbl>

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: efficacy_table() function takes pool object produces regulatory-style gt table format commonly seen ICH/CDISC Table 14.2.x submissions. displays LS means arm, treatment differences, confidence intervals, p-values, organised visit. can customise table descriptive titles treatment arm labels match study protocol: returned object standard gt table, can apply gt customisation top. example, add footnotes, adjust column widths, change table styling using gt::tab_options().
code: tbl <- efficacy_table(pool_obj) tbl tbl_custom <- efficacy_table(   pool_obj,   title = "Table 14.2.1: ANCOVA of Change from Baseline",   subtitle = "Reference-Based Multiple Imputation (Jump to Reference)",   arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A") ) tbl_custom

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: plot_forest() function creates three-panel forest plot: text panel visit labels formatted estimates, graphical panel point estimates confidence interval whiskers, p-value panel.

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: default display = "trt" mode shows treatment differences across visits, vertical reference line zero. Filled circles indicate visits confidence interval excludes zero (statistically significant); open circles indicate non-significant results.
code: p <- plot_forest(   pool_obj,   title = "Treatment Effect: Change from Baseline (Drug A vs Placebo)" ) p

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: display = "lsm" mode shows LS mean estimates treatment arm, colour-coded using Okabe-Ito colourblind-friendly palette.  plot modes return patchwork object can customise using & theme() operator. example, increase text size across panels:
code: p_lsm <- plot_forest(   pool_obj,   display = "lsm",   arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A"),   title = "LS Mean Estimates by Visit" ) p_lsm plot_forest(pool_obj) & ggplot2::theme(text = ggplot2::element_text(size = 14))

title: From rbmi Analysis to Regulatory Tables
text: pipeline binary responder endpoints follows overall structure, differs two key ways: analysis function uses g-computation logistic regression instead ANCOVA, responder variable derived continuous outcome. section, use pre-computed ADMI dataset bundled rbmiUtils. dataset already contains 100 imputed copies trial data binary responder variable (CRIT1FLN), skip draws() impute() steps. gcomp_responder_multi() function applies g-computation via beeca visit. fits logistic regression model uses method Ge et al. estimate covariate-adjusted marginal treatment effects. reporting functions work seamlessly binary pool object:  demonstrates efficacy_table() plot_forest() output-agnostic: work pool object produced rbmi pipeline, whether underlying analysis used ANCOVA continuous endpoint g-computation binary one.
code: data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils")  ADMI_binary <- ADMI |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT),     STRATA = factor(STRATA),     REGION = factor(REGION)   ) vars_binary <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CRIT1FLN",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) method_binary <- method_bayes(   n_samples = 100,   control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) ) ana_obj_binary <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI_binary,   vars = vars_binary,   method = method_binary,   fun = gcomp_responder_multi,   reference_levels = "Placebo" ) #> Warning: `extract_covariates2()` was deprecated in rbmiUtils 0.2.0. #> ℹ Internal helper will be removed in a future version. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the rbmiUtils package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/openpharma/rbmiUtils/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once per session. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. #> Warning: `as_simple_formula2()` was deprecated in rbmiUtils 0.2.0. #> ℹ Internal helper will be removed in a future version. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the rbmiUtils package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/openpharma/rbmiUtils/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once per session. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. pool_obj_binary <- pool(ana_obj_binary) print(pool_obj_binary) #>  #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>                   parameter                  visit   est   lci   uci    pval #>  trt_Drug A-Placebo_Week 24 Drug A-Placebo_Week 24 -0.03 -0.05 -0.01   0.007 #>          lsm_Drug A_Week 24                Week 24  0.00  0.00  0.00   0.921 #>         lsm_Placebo_Week 24                Week 24  0.03  0.01  0.05   0.007 #>  trt_Drug A-Placebo_Week 48 Drug A-Placebo_Week 48 -0.10 -0.14 -0.05 < 0.001 #>          lsm_Drug A_Week 48                Week 48  0.01  0.00  0.02   0.150 #>         lsm_Placebo_Week 48                Week 48  0.10  0.06  0.14 < 0.001 tidy_pool_obj(pool_obj_binary) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   parameter  description visit parameter_type lsm_type      est      se      lci #>   <chr>      <chr>       <chr> <chr>          <chr>       <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1 trt_Drug … Treatment … Drug… trt            NA       -3.08e-2 1.15e-2 -0.0534  #> 2 lsm_Drug … Least Squa… Week… lsm            Drug A    7.79e-5 7.85e-4 -0.00146 #> 3 lsm_Place… Least Squa… Week… lsm            Placebo   3.09e-2 1.15e-2  0.00843 #> 4 trt_Drug … Treatment … Drug… trt            NA       -9.57e-2 2.10e-2 -0.137   #> 5 lsm_Drug … Least Squa… Week… lsm            Drug A    7.27e-3 5.04e-3 -0.00262 #> 6 lsm_Place… Least Squa… Week… lsm            Placebo   1.03e-1 2.06e-2  0.0627  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: uci <dbl>, pval <dbl> efficacy_table(   pool_obj_binary,   title = "Table 14.2.2: Responder Analysis (CHG > 3)",   subtitle = "G-computation with Marginal Effects",   arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A") ) plot_forest(   pool_obj_binary,   title = "Responder Rate Difference (Drug A vs Placebo)" )

what: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
text: rbmiUtils bridges rbmi analysis results publication-ready regulatory tables forest plots. extends rbmi clinical trial workflows, handling everything data validation formatted efficacy outputs.

title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
text: can install package CRAN development version GitHub:

title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
text: rbmiUtils extends rbmi pipeline raw data publication-ready outputs. complete workflow using bundled ADEFF dataset: Forest Plot Forest Plot Efficacy Table Efficacy Table See end--end pipeline vignette complete walkthrough raw data outputs.
code: library(rbmiUtils) library(rbmi) library(dplyr)  # Load example efficacy dataset and prepare factors data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils") ADEFF <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT, levels = c("Week 24", "Week 48"))   )  # Define analysis variables vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") )  # Configure Bayesian imputation method method <- method_bayes(   n_samples = 100,   control = control_bayes(warmup = 200, thin = 2) )  # Step 1: Fit imputation model (draws) dat <- ADEFF |> select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT) draws_obj <- draws(data = dat, vars = vars, method = method)  # Step 2: Generate imputed datasets impute_obj <- impute(   draws_obj,   references = c("Placebo" = "Placebo", "Drug A" = "Placebo") )  # Step 3: Extract stacked imputed data ADMI <- get_imputed_data(impute_obj)  # Step 4: Analyse each imputed dataset ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(data = ADMI, vars = vars, method = method, fun = ancova)  # Step 5: Pool results using Rubin's rules pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj)  # Publication-ready outputs efficacy_table(pool_obj, arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A")) plot_forest(pool_obj, arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A"))

title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
text: validate_data() – pre-flight checks data structure imputation analyse_mi_data() – run ANCOVA (custom analysis) across imputations tidy_pool_obj() – tidy pooled results visit-level annotations efficacy_table() – regulatory-style gt tables (CDISC/ICH Table 14.2.x format) plot_forest() – three-panel forest plots estimates, CIs, p-values pool_to_ard() – convert pool objects pharmaverse ARD format optional MI diagnostic enrichment (FMI, lambda, RIV) get_imputed_data() – extract long-format imputed datasets describe_draws() – inspect draws objects (method, samples, convergence diagnostics) describe_imputation() – inspect imputation objects (method, M, missingness breakdown) format_pvalue() / format_estimate() – publication-ready formatting

title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend rbmi
text: rbmi Analysis Regulatory Tables – end--end walkthrough raw data regulatory outputs Storing Analyzing Imputed Data – focused guide analysis workflows MI Diagnostics Describe Helpers – inspecting draws, imputations, MI diagnostic statistics Package documentation

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
text: function applies analysis function (e.g., ANCOVA) imputed datasets stores results later pooling. designed work multiple imputed datasets apply given analysis function imputation iteration.

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
code: analyse_mi_data(   data = NULL,   vars = NULL,   method = NULL,   fun = rbmi::ancova,   delta = NULL,   ... )

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
text: data data frame containing imputed datasets. data frame include variable (e.g., IMPID) identifies distinct imputation iterations. Typically obtained get_imputed_data() expand_imputed_data(). vars list specifying key variables used analysis (e.g., subjid, visit, group, outcome). Created using rbmi::set_vars(). Required. method method object specifying imputation method used (e.g., Bayesian imputation). Created using rbmi::method_bayes(), rbmi::method_approxbayes(), rbmi::method_condmean(). Required. fun function applied imputed dataset. Defaults rbmi::ancova. options include gcomp_responder_multi() binary outcomes. Must valid analysis function. delta data.frame used delta adjustments, NULL delta adjustments needed. Defaults NULL. Must contain columns matching vars$subjid, vars$visit, vars$group, delta column. ... Additional arguments passed analysis function fun.

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
text: object class analysis containing results applying analysis function imputed dataset. Pass rbmi::pool() obtain pooled estimates.

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
text: function loops distinct imputation datasets (identified IMPID), applies provided analysis function fun, stores results later pooling. delta dataset provided, merged imputed data apply specified delta adjustment analysis. Workflow: Prepare imputed data using get_imputed_data() expand_imputed_data() Define variables using rbmi::set_vars() Call analyse_mi_data() apply analysis imputation Pool results using rbmi::pool() Tidy results using tidy_pool_obj()

title: Apply Analysis Function to Multiple Imputed Datasets — analyse_mi_data
code: # Example usage with an ANCOVA function library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils) set.seed(123) data("ADMI")  # Convert key columns to factors ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")) ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID) ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)  # Define key variables for ANCOVA analysis  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION")  # Covariates for adjustment  )  # Specify the imputation method (Bayesian) - need for pool step  method <- rbmi::method_bayes(  n_samples = 20,  control = rbmi::control_bayes(    warmup = 20,    thin = 1    )  )  # Perform ANCOVA Analysis on Each Imputed Dataset ana_obj_ancova <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI,   vars = vars,   method = method,   fun = ancova,  # Apply ANCOVA   delta = NULL   # No sensitivity analysis adjustment ) #> Warning: Data contains 100 imputations but method expects 20. Using first 20 #> imputations.

what: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
text: Extracts structured metadata rbmi draws object, including method, formula, sample count, failures, covariance structure, (Bayesian methods) MCMC convergence diagnostics. Returns S3 object informative print() method.

title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
code: describe_draws(draws_obj)

title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
text: draws_obj draws object returned rbmi::draws().

title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
text: S3 object class c("describe_draws", "list") containing: method Human-readable method name (e.g., "Bayesian (MCMC via Stan)") method_class Raw class name: "bayes", "approxbayes", "condmean" n_samples Total number samples n_failures Number failed samples formula Deparsed model formula string covariance Covariance structure (e.g., "us") same_cov Logical; whether covariance used across groups condmean_type (condmean ) "jackknife" "bootstrap" n_primary (condmean ) Always 1 n_resampled (condmean ) Number resampled draws bayes_control (bayes ) List warmup, thin, chains, seed mcmc (bayes stanfit ) List rhat, ess, max_rhat, min_ess, n_params, converged

title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
text: conditional mean methods, sample count displayed "1 + N" matching rbmi convention first sample primary (full-data) fit remaining N jackknife bootstrap resamples. Bayesian methods, MCMC convergence diagnostics (ESS, Rhat) extracted stanfit object rstan available. converged flag uses Rhat < 1.1 threshold matching rbmi's convention.

title: Describe an rbmi Draws Object — describe_draws
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(rbmi) library(dplyr) data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils")  # Prepare ADEFF data for rbmi pipeline ADEFF <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT, levels = c("Week 24", "Week 48"))   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) dat <- ADEFF |> select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT) draws_obj <- draws(   data = dat, vars = vars,   method = method_bayes(n_samples = 100) )  # Inspect the draws object desc <- describe_draws(draws_obj) print(desc)  # Programmatic access to metadata desc$method desc$n_samples desc$formula } # }

title: Describe an rbmi Imputation Object — describe_imputation
text: missingness table built cross-tabulating impute_obj$data$is_missing visit treatment group. row shows total number subjects group, many missing data visit, percentage missing.

title: Describe an rbmi Imputation Object — describe_imputation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(rbmi) library(dplyr) data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils")  ADEFF <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = factor(TRT01P, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")),     USUBJID = factor(USUBJID),     AVISIT = factor(AVISIT, levels = c("Week 24", "Week 48"))   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) dat <- ADEFF |> select(USUBJID, STRATA, REGION, TRT, BASE, CHG, AVISIT) draws_obj <- draws(   data = dat, vars = vars,   method = method_bayes(n_samples = 100) ) impute_obj <- impute(   draws_obj,   references = c("Placebo" = "Placebo", "Drug A" = "Placebo") )  # Inspect the imputation desc <- describe_imputation(impute_obj) print(desc)  # Programmatic access desc$n_imputations desc$missingness desc$references } # }

what: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
text: Takes rbmi pool object produces publication-ready gt table style CDISC/ICH Table 14.2.x. table displays least squares means treatment arm, treatment differences, confidence intervals, p-values, organized visit row groups.

title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
code: efficacy_table(   pool_obj,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   digits = 2,   ci_level = NULL,   arm_labels = NULL,   pval_digits = 3,   pval_threshold = 0.001,   font_family = NULL,   font_size = NULL,   row_padding = NULL,   ... )

title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
text: pool_obj pooled analysis object class "pool", typically obtained rbmi::pool() calling analyse_mi_data(). title Optional character string table title. subtitle Optional character string table subtitle. digits Integer. Number decimal places estimates standard errors. Default 2. ci_level Numeric. Confidence level CI column labeling. NULL (default), extracted pool_obj$conf.level. Falls back 0.95 neither available. arm_labels Named character vector elements "ref" "alt" providing custom labels reference treatment arms. NULL (default), uses "Reference" "Treatment". pval_digits Integer. Number decimal places p-values. Default 3. pval_threshold Numeric. P-values threshold displayed "< threshold". Default 0.001. font_family Optional character string specifying font family table. NULL (default), uses gt's default font. Applied via gt::opt_table_font(). font_size Optional numeric value specifying table font size pixels. NULL (default), uses gt's default size. Applied via gt::tab_options(). row_padding Optional numeric value specifying vertical padding data rows pixels. NULL (default), uses gt's default padding. Smaller values (e.g., 2-3) create compact regulatory-style tables. ... Additional arguments passed gt::gt().

title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
text: gt table object class gt_tbl.

title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
text: function assumes single-parameter-per-visit pool object (standard output rbmi ANCOVA MMRM pipeline). internally calls tidy_pool_obj() parse pool object, constructs gt table. Arm labels: Use arm_labels parameter customize arm names table. example, arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug ") display "LS Mean (Placebo)" "LS Mean (Drug )" instead defaults. Customization: returned gt object can customized using standard gt piping, e.g., efficacy_table(pool_obj) |> gt::tab_options(...). Example output:

title: Create Regulatory-Style Efficacy Summary Table — efficacy_table
code: # \donttest{ if (requireNamespace("gt", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(rbmi)   data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils")   ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A"))   ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID)   ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)    vars <- set_vars(     subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",     outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION")   )   method <- method_bayes(     n_samples = 20,     control = control_bayes(warmup = 20, thin = 1)   )    ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(ADMI, vars, method, fun = ancova)   pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj)    # Basic table   tbl <- efficacy_table(pool_obj)    # Publication-styled table   efficacy_table(     pool_obj,     title = "Table 14.2.1: ANCOVA of Change from Baseline",     subtitle = "Mixed Model for Repeated Measures",     arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A"),     font_size = 12,     row_padding = 4   ) } #> Warning: Data contains 100 imputations but method expects 20. Using first 20 #> imputations.     Table 14.2.1: ANCOVA of Change from Baseline     Mixed Model for Repeated Measures            Estimate       Std. Error       95% CI       P-value     Week 24     LS Mean (Placebo) 0.09 0.13 (-0.17, 0.34) 0.514LS Mean (Drug A) −2.10 0.13 (-2.34, -1.85) < 0.001Treatment Difference −2.18 0.18 (-2.54, -1.82) < 0.001Week 48     LS Mean (Placebo) 0.04 0.19 (-0.33, 0.40) 0.846LS Mean (Drug A) −3.76 0.18 (-4.11, -3.41) < 0.001Treatment Difference −3.79 0.26 (-4.30, -3.29) < 0.001Pooling method: rubin     Number of imputations: 20     Confidence level: 95%     # }

code: library(rbmi) library(dplyr)  # Example with package data data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils") data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils")  # Prepare original data to match ADMI structure original <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = TRT01P,     USUBJID = as.character(USUBJID)   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG" )  # Reduce and then expand reduced <- reduce_imputed_data(ADMI, original, vars) expanded <- expand_imputed_data(reduced, original, vars)  # Verify expansion cat("Original ADMI rows:", nrow(ADMI), "\n") #> Original ADMI rows: 100000  cat("Expanded rows:", nrow(expanded), "\n") #> Expanded rows: 100000

what: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
text: Takes rbmi pool object produces publication-quality, three-panel forest plot using ggplot2 patchwork. plot displays treatment effect point estimates confidence interval whiskers, aligned table panel showing formatted estimates, p-value panel.

title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
code: plot_forest(   pool_obj,   display = c("trt", "lsm"),   ref_value = NULL,   ci_level = NULL,   arm_labels = NULL,   title = NULL,   text_size = 3,   point_size = 3,   show_pvalues = TRUE,   font_family = NULL,   panel_widths = NULL )

title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
text: pool_obj pooled analysis object class "pool", typically obtained rbmi::pool() calling analyse_mi_data(). display Character string specifying display mode. "trt" (default) shows treatment differences across visits. "lsm" shows LS mean estimates treatment arm color-coded points. ref_value Numeric. reference value vertical reference line. Default 0 display = "trt" NULL (line) display = "lsm". Set explicitly override. ci_level Numeric. Confidence level CI labeling. NULL (default), extracted pool_obj$conf.level. Falls back 0.95 neither available. arm_labels Named character vector elements "ref" "alt" providing custom labels reference treatment arms display = "lsm". NULL (default), uses "Reference" "Treatment". title Optional character string plot title. text_size Numeric. Text size table p-value panels. Default 3. point_size Numeric. Point size forest plot. Default 3. show_pvalues Logical. Whether display p-value panel right side plot. Default TRUE. Set FALSE cleaner two-panel layout without p-values. font_family Optional character string specifying font family text plot. NULL (default), uses ggplot2's default font (typically sans-serif). Applied geom_text layers forest panel theme. panel_widths Optional numeric vector controlling relative widths plot panels. show_pvalues = TRUE, must length 3 (table, forest, p-value panels). show_pvalues = FALSE, must length 2 (table, forest panels). NULL (default), uses c(3, 4, 1.5) 3-panel c(3, 5) 2-panel layouts.

title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
text: patchwork/ggplot object can customized using & theme() modify panels simultaneously.

title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
text: function calls tidy_pool_obj() internally parse pool object, constructs three-panel composition: Left panel: Visit labels formatted estimate CI text Middle panel: Forest plot point estimates CI whiskers Right panel: Formatted p-values Display modes: "trt" – Treatment differences reference line zero (custom ref_value). Significant results (CI excludes reference) shown filled circles; non-significant open circles. "lsm" – LS mean estimates treatment arm, color-coded using Okabe-Ito colorblind-friendly palette (blue reference, vermilion treatment). Points dodged vertically within visit. Customization: returned patchwork object supports & theme() applying theme changes panels. example: plot_forest(pool_obj) & theme(text = element_text(size = 14)). Example output (treatment difference mode):

title: Create a Forest Plot from an rbmi Pool Object — plot_forest
code: # \donttest{ if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("patchwork", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(rbmi)   data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils")   ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A"))   ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID)   ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)    vars <- set_vars(     subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",     outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION")   )   method <- method_bayes(     n_samples = 20,     control = control_bayes(warmup = 20, thin = 1)   )    ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(ADMI, vars, method, fun = ancova)   pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj)    # Treatment difference forest plot   plot_forest(pool_obj, arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A"))    # LSM display with custom panel widths   plot_forest(     pool_obj,     display = "lsm",     arm_labels = c(ref = "Placebo", alt = "Drug A"),     title = "LS Mean Estimates by Visit",     panel_widths = c(3, 5, 1.5)   ) } #> Warning: Data contains 100 imputations but method expects 20. Using first 20 #> imputations.  # }

what: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
text: Converts rbmi pool object pharmaverse Analysis Results Dataset (ARD) standard using cards package. ARD format long-format data frame row represents single statistic given parameter, grouping columns visit, parameter type, least-squares-mean type.

title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
code: pool_to_ard(pool_obj, analysis_obj = NULL, conf.level = NULL)

title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
text: pool_obj pooled analysis object class "pool", typically obtained rbmi::pool() calling analyse_mi_data(). analysis_obj optional analysis object (output analyse_mi_data()), used compute MI diagnostic statistics. provided pooling method Rubin's rules, ARD includes additional stat rows FMI, lambda, RIV, Barnard-Rubin adjusted df, complete-data df, relative efficiency, number imputations per parameter. NULL (default), base ARD returned. conf.level Confidence level used CI labels (e.g., 0.95 produces "95% CI Lower"). NULL (default), value taken pool_obj$conf.level. also NULL, defaults 0.95.

title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
text: data frame class "card" (ARD format) grouping columns visit (group1), parameter_type (group2), lsm_type (group3). parameter produces rows five statistics: estimate, std.error, conf.low, conf.high, p.value, plus method row. analysis_obj provided pooling method Rubin's rules, additional diagnostic stat rows included: fmi, lambda, riv, df.adjusted, df.complete, re, m.imputations.

title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
text: function works : Tidying pool object via tidy_pool_obj() Reshaping parameter long-format ARD rows (one row per statistic) Adding grouping columns (visit, parameter_type, lsm_type) Optionally enriching MI diagnostic statistics analysis_obj provided Applying cards::as_card() cards::tidy_ard_column_order() standard ARD structure analysis_obj provided: Rubin's rules pooling: diagnostic statistics (FMI, lambda, RIV, Barnard-Rubin adjusted df, relative efficiency) computed per parameter using per-imputation estimates, standard errors, degrees freedom. non-Rubin pooling methods: informative message emitted base ARD returned without diagnostic rows. resulting ARD passes cards::check_ard_structure() validation suitable downstream use gtsummary.

title: Convert Pool Object to ARD Format — pool_to_ard
code: # \donttest{ if (requireNamespace("cards", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(rbmi)   data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils")   ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A"))   ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID)   ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)    vars <- set_vars(     subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",     outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION")   )   method <- method_bayes(     n_samples = 20,     control = control_bayes(warmup = 20, thin = 1)   )    ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(ADMI, vars, method, fun = ancova)   pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj)    # Base ARD   ard <- pool_to_ard(pool_obj)    # Enriched ARD with MI diagnostics (FMI, lambda, RIV, df)   ard_diag <- pool_to_ard(pool_obj, analysis_obj = ana_obj) } #> Warning: Data contains 100 imputations but method expects 20. Using first 20 #> imputations. # }

title: Prepare Intercurrent Event Data — prepare_data_ice
text: Builds data_ice data.frame column dataset flags intercurrent events. subject, first visit (factor level order) flag TRUE used ICE visit.

title: Prepare Intercurrent Event Data — prepare_data_ice
code: prepare_data_ice(data, vars, ice_col, strategy)

title: Prepare Intercurrent Event Data — prepare_data_ice
text: data data.frame containing analysis dataset. vars vars object created rbmi::set_vars(). ice_col Character string naming column data indicates ICE occurrence. Accepted values logical (TRUE/FALSE), character ("Y"/"N"), numeric (1/0). strategy Character string specifying imputation strategy assign. Must one "MAR", "CR", "JR", "CIR", "LMCF".

title: Prepare Intercurrent Event Data — prepare_data_ice
text: data.frame columns corresponding vars$subjid, vars$visit, vars$strategy, suitable passing rbmi::draws().

title: Prepare Intercurrent Event Data — prepare_data_ice
code: library(rbmi)  dat <- data.frame(   USUBJID = factor(rep(c("S1", "S2", "S3"), each = 3)),   AVISIT = factor(rep(c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12"), 3),                   levels = c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12")),   TRT = factor(rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A", "Drug A"), each = 3)),   CHG = rnorm(9),   DISCFL = c("N","N","N", "N","Y","Y", "N","N","Y") )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG" )  ice <- prepare_data_ice(dat, vars, ice_col = "DISCFL", strategy = "JR") print(ice) #>   USUBJID  AVISIT strategy #> 1      S2  Week 8       JR #> 2      S3 Week 12       JR

title: Print Method for Pool Objects — print.pool
text: method overrides rbmi::print.pool() provide enhanced, formatted console output using cli package. override produces "Registered S3 method overwritten" message package load time, expected harmless (pattern print.analysis()). output includes: header parameter visit counts Metadata: pooling method, number imputations, confidence level compact results table key columns: parameter, visit, est, lci, uci, pval

title: Print Method for Pool Objects — print.pool
code: # \donttest{ library(rbmi) library(rbmiUtils) data("ADMI")  ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")) ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID) ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID", visit = "AVISIT", group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG", covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION") ) method <- method_bayes(n_samples = 20, control = control_bayes(warmup = 20))  ana_obj <- analyse_mi_data(ADMI, vars, method, fun = ancova) #> Warning: Data contains 100 imputations but method expects 20. Using first 20 #> imputations. pool_obj <- pool(ana_obj) print(pool_obj) #>  #> Pool Object #> ----------- #> Number of Results Combined: 20 #> Method: rubin #> Confidence Level: 0.95 #> Alternative: two.sided #>  #> Results: #>  #>   ======================================================== #>       parameter      est     se     lci     uci     pval   #>   -------------------------------------------------------- #>      trt_Week 24    -2.181  0.182  -2.539  -1.823  <0.001  #>    lsm_ref_Week 24  0.086   0.132  -0.173  0.344   0.514   #>    lsm_alt_Week 24  -2.096  0.126  -2.344  -1.847  <0.001  #>      trt_Week 48    -3.794  0.256  -4.297  -3.29   <0.001  #>    lsm_ref_Week 48  0.036   0.186  -0.33   0.403   0.846   #>    lsm_alt_Week 48  -3.758  0.177  -4.106  -3.409  <0.001  #>   -------------------------------------------------------- #>  # }

what: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend the 'rbmi' Package — rbmiUtils-package
title: rbmiUtils: Utility Functions to Support and Extend the 'rbmi' Package — rbmiUtils-package
text: Provides utility functions extend capabilities reference-based multiple imputation package 'rbmi'. supports clinical trial analysis workflows functions managing imputed datasets, applying analysis methods across imputations, tidying results reporting.

what: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
text: Extracts imputed records (originally missing) full imputed dataset. significantly reduces storage requirements working many imputations, observed values identical across imputations need stored original data.

title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
code: reduce_imputed_data(imputed_data, original_data, vars)

title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
text: imputed_data data.frame containing full imputed dataset IMPID column identifying imputation. Typically output get_imputed_data(). original_data data.frame containing original dataset imputation, missing values outcome column. vars vars object created rbmi::set_vars().

title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
text: data.frame containing rows imputed_data correspond originally missing outcome values. columns imputed_data preserved.

title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
text: Storage savings depend proportion missing data. example: Original: 1000 rows, 44 missing values Full imputed (1000 imputations): 1,000,000 rows Reduced (1000 imputations): 44,000 rows (4.4\ Use expand_imputed_data() reconstruct full imputed dataset needed analysis.

title: Reduce Imputed Data for Efficient Storage — reduce_imputed_data
code:
library(rbmi) library(dplyr)  # Example with package data data("ADMI", package = "rbmiUtils") data("ADEFF", package = "rbmiUtils")  # Prepare original data to match ADMI structure original <- ADEFF |>   mutate(     TRT = TRT01P,     USUBJID = as.character(USUBJID)   )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG" )  # Reduce to only imputed values reduced <- reduce_imputed_data(ADMI, original, vars)  # Compare sizes cat("Full imputed rows:", nrow(ADMI), "
") #> Full imputed rows: 100000  cat("Reduced rows:", nrow(reduced), "
") #> Reduced rows: 4400  cat("Compression:", round(100 * nrow(reduced) / nrow(ADMI), 1), "%
") #> Compression: 4.4 %

title: Summarise Missing Data Patterns — summarise_missingness
text: data data.frame containing analysis dataset one row per subject-visit combination. vars vars object created rbmi::set_vars().

title: Summarise Missing Data Patterns — summarise_missingness
text: list three components: by_visit tibble columns: visit, group, n, n_miss, pct_miss patterns tibble columns: subjid, group, pattern ("complete", "monotone", "intermittent"), dropout_visit (NA monotone) summary tibble columns: group, n_subjects, n_complete, n_monotone, n_intermittent

title: Summarise Missing Data Patterns — summarise_missingness
code: library(rbmi)  dat <- data.frame(   USUBJID = factor(rep(c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4"), each = 3)),   AVISIT = factor(rep(c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12"), 4),                   levels = c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12")),   TRT = factor(rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A"), each = 6)),   CHG = c(1, 2, 3, 1, NA, NA, 1, 2, NA, 1, NA, 2) )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG" )  result <- summarise_missingness(dat, vars) print(result$by_visit) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   visit   group       n n_miss pct_miss #>   <fct>   <fct>   <int>  <int>    <dbl> #> 1 Week 4  Drug A      2      0        0 #> 2 Week 4  Placebo     2      0        0 #> 3 Week 8  Drug A      2      1       50 #> 4 Week 8  Placebo     2      1       50 #> 5 Week 12 Drug A      2      1       50 #> 6 Week 12 Placebo     2      1       50 print(result$patterns) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   USUBJID TRT     pattern      dropout_visit #>   <fct>   <chr>   <chr>        <chr>         #> 1 S1      Placebo complete     NA            #> 2 S2      Placebo monotone     Week 8        #> 3 S3      Drug A  monotone     Week 12       #> 4 S4      Drug A  intermittent NA            print(result$summary) #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   group   n_subjects n_complete n_monotone n_intermittent #>   <chr>        <int>      <int>      <int>          <int> #> 1 Drug A           2          0          1              1 #> 2 Placebo          2          1          1              0

what: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
text: function processes pooled analysis object class pool tidy tibble format. adds contextual information, whether parameter treatment comparison least squares mean, dynamically identifies visit names parameter column, provides additional columns parameter type, least squares mean type, visit.

title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
code: tidy_pool_obj(pool_obj)

title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
text: pool_obj pooled analysis object class pool, typically obtained rbmi::pool() calling analyse_mi_data().

title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
text: tibble containing processed pooled analysis results following columns: parameter Original parameter name pooled object description Human-readable description parameter visit Visit name extracted parameter (applicable) parameter_type Either "trt" (treatment comparison) "lsm" (least squares mean) lsm_type LSM parameters: "ref" (reference) "alt" (alternative) est Point estimate se Standard error lci Lower confidence interval uci Upper confidence interval pval P-value

title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
text: function dynamically processes parameter column separating components (e.g., type estimate, reference vs. alternative arm, visit), provides informative descriptions output. Workflow: Prepare data run imputation rbmi Analyse analyse_mi_data() Pool rbmi::pool() Tidy tidy_pool_obj() publication-ready output

title: Tidy and Annotate a Pooled Object for Publication — tidy_pool_obj
code: # Example usage: library(dplyr) library(rbmi)  data("ADMI") N_IMPUTATIONS <- 100 BURN_IN <- 200 BURN_BETWEEN <- 5  # Convert key columns to factors ADMI$TRT <- factor(ADMI$TRT, levels = c("Placebo", "Drug A")) ADMI$USUBJID <- factor(ADMI$USUBJID) ADMI$AVISIT <- factor(ADMI$AVISIT)  # Define key variables for ANCOVA analysis  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA", "REGION")  # Covariates for adjustment  )  # Specify the imputation method (Bayesian) - need for pool step method <- rbmi::method_bayes(   n_samples = N_IMPUTATIONS,   control = rbmi::control_bayes(     warmup = BURN_IN,     thin = BURN_BETWEEN     )   )  # Perform ANCOVA Analysis on Each Imputed Dataset ana_obj_ancova <- analyse_mi_data(   data = ADMI,   vars = vars,   method = method,   fun = ancova,  # Apply ANCOVA   delta = NULL   # No sensitivity analysis adjustment )  pool_obj_ancova <- pool(ana_obj_ancova) tidy_df <- tidy_pool_obj(pool_obj_ancova)  # Print tidy data frames print(tidy_df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>   parameter       description visit parameter_type lsm_type     est    se    lci #>   <chr>           <chr>       <chr> <chr>          <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 trt_Week 24     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -2.17   0.182 -2.53  #> 2 lsm_ref_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0782 0.131 -0.179 #> 3 lsm_alt_Week 24 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -2.09   0.126 -2.34  #> 4 trt_Week 48     Treatment … Week… trt            NA       -3.81   0.256 -4.31  #> 5 lsm_ref_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            ref       0.0481 0.185 -0.316 #> 6 lsm_alt_Week 48 Least Squa… Week… lsm            alt      -3.76   0.176 -4.11  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: uci <dbl>, pval <dbl>

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
text: Pre-flight validation data, variable specification, intercurrent event data calling rbmi::draws(). Collects issues reports together single error message.

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
code: validate_data(data, vars, data_ice = NULL)

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
text: data data.frame containing analysis dataset. vars vars object created rbmi::set_vars(). data_ice optional data.frame intercurrent events. provided, must contain columns corresponding vars$subjid, vars$visit, vars$strategy. Can created using prepare_data_ice().

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
text: Invisibly returns TRUE checks pass. Throws error collected messages issues found.

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
text: following checks performed: data data.frame columns named vars exist data subjid, visit, group columns factors outcome column numeric Covariate columns missing values Data one row per subject-visit combination data_ice provided: correct columns, valid subjects, valid visits, recognised strategies, one row per subject Recommended Workflow: Call validate_data() check data Use prepare_data_ice() create ICE data needed Review missingness summarise_missingness() Proceed rbmi::draws() imputation

title: Validate Data Before Imputation — validate_data
code: library(rbmi)  dat <- data.frame(   USUBJID = factor(rep(c("S1", "S2", "S3"), each = 3)),   AVISIT = factor(rep(c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12"), 3),                   levels = c("Week 4", "Week 8", "Week 12")),   TRT = factor(rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A", "Drug A"), each = 3)),   CHG = c(1.1, 2.2, 3.3, 0.5, NA, NA, 1.0, 2.0, NA),   BASE = rep(c(10, 12, 11), each = 3),   STRATA = factor(rep(c("A", "B", "A"), each = 3)) )  vars <- set_vars(   subjid = "USUBJID",   visit = "AVISIT",   group = "TRT",   outcome = "CHG",   covariates = c("BASE", "STRATA") )  validate_data(dat, vars)

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.2
text: describe_draws() extracts structured metadata rbmi draws objects, including method type, formula, sample count, (Bayesian methods) MCMC convergence diagnostics (ESS, Rhat). describe_imputation() extracts imputation metadata including method, number imputations (M), reference arm mappings, missingness breakdown visit treatment arm. pool_to_ard() gains analysis_obj parameter enriches ARD MI diagnostic statistics (FMI, lambda, RIV, Barnard-Rubin adjusted df, relative efficiency) pooling method Rubin’s rules.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.2
text: efficacy_table() gains font_family, font_size, row_padding parameters publication-ready table styling. plot_forest() gains font_family panel_widths parameters customizable typography panel layout. plot_forest() left panel now uses left-aligned text (hjust=0) consistent positioning regardless label length. Non-Rubin pooling methods now emit informative cli::cli_inform() message MI diagnostics applicable, rather returning NA rows.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.1
text: End--end pipeline vignette “rbmi Analysis Regulatory Tables” continuous binary analysis walkthroughs. README enhanced rendered efficacy table forest plot visual teasers. Rendered example output images plot_forest() efficacy_table() help pages. Inline cross-references rbmi beeca documentation vignettes.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.1
text: validate_data() now uses cli-formatted error messages clearer guidance malformed interaction terms, empty data, type mismatches. prepare_data_ice() now errors immediately vars$strategy NULL instead silently using default column name. prepare_data_ice() warns visit column character guidance convert factor correct ordering. validate_data() batches type coercion warnings single message warns -NA covariate columns. Data preparation functions handle edge cases (single subject, single visit, -NA outcome, -complete data) gracefully.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.0
text: tidy_pool_obj() now uses regex-based parameter parsing instead splitting _. Output columns (parameter_type, lsm_type, visit) now contain full visit name rather truncated fragments.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.0
text: efficacy_table() creates regulatory-style gt summary tables pool objects. plot_forest() creates publication-quality three-panel forest plots pool objects. pool_to_ard() converts pool objects pharmaverse ARD format via cards package. print() summary() S3 methods pool analysis objects. create_impid() converts lists imputed datasets stacked data.frames. combine_results() combines tidy results multiple analyses. format_results() format_results_table() publication-ready formatting. extract_trt_effects() extract_lsm() convenience filters tidy results.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.0
text: Added cli (>= 3.6.0) lifecycle (>= 1.0.4) Imports improved error messaging deprecation support.

title: rbmiUtils 0.2.0
text: Enhanced input validation analyse_mi_data() clearer error messages using inherits() instead internal class helpers. Enhanced input validation prepare_data_ice() check vars fields. Cross-references related functions documentation. Expanded test coverage integration tests.

title: rbmiUtils 0.1.9
text: reduce_imputed_data() expand_imputed_data() efficient storage imputed datasets. validate_data() pre-flight validation rbmi::draws(). prepare_data_ice() build data_ice flagged ICE columns. summarise_missingness() tabulating missing data patterns. format_pvalue(), format_estimate(), format_results_table() formatting utilities. ADEFF ADMI example datasets. Initial documentation via pkgdown.
